SECURITY AND PRIVACY ISSUES

Not a day goes by when there is a data breach or ransomware attack. What concerns this is that with the prevalence of IoT and Industrial IoT, all these connected devices are all over the place, and some of these devices are not manufactured with security in mind. The World Economic Forum defines this period as a paradigm shift across industry verticals in which new technologies are fusing the physical, digital, and biological worlds. This fusing of physical and digital technologies, a significant trend that underlines these momentous advances, is also the convergence of informational and operational technologies, or the IT/OT convergence. A traditional IT environment - including computers, servers and a whole range of IoT devices- can comprise the conventional cyber ecosystem. But when this IT environment begins communicating with an OT environment, such as manufacturing equipment or machines or other sensors and operational technologies, this becomes a cyber-physical ecosystem. A cyber-physical ecosystem, or other sensors and active technologies, becomes a cyber-physical ecosystem. A cyber-physical ecosystem. Where the door is open to cyber-physical threats, that is, attacks that gain an initial hold in an IT environment but then move over to disrupt operations in the OT environment. For example, an attack originating in the inbox or anywhere else on an IT network can then go on to disrupt the processes directly on the factory floor. And this is precisely what happened recently with the EKANS ransomware. So, in June 2020, when Honda announced that it was halting industrial operations in factories across the globe, spanning everywhere from India to Ohio, the security industry became acutely aware of new risks to industrial processes. Honda was hit with a form of ransomware which frequently targets corporate networks in attempts to either hold data hostage or otherwise forcibly interrupt critical business practices and then demand the ransom. However, this strain had a unique twist. Namely, EKANS was one of the strains of ransomware 'caught in the wild' that mainly targets processes related to industrial operations in its kill chain. This EKANS ransomware directly targeted vulnerabilities in industrial control systems. Or ICS, the computers that control manufacturing and other physical processes- in its targeting of 65 ICS mechanisms in its 'Kill List,' the list of methods the ransomware interrupts to dispute industrial operations.


The Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack is a cyberattack that causes the servers to refuse to provide services to genuine clients. The DDOS attack can be classified into two types:
    Flooding attacks: In this attack, the hacker sends massive traffic to the server, which the server cannot handle. And hence, the server stops functioning. This attack type is usually executed using automated programs that continuously send packets to the server.
    Crash attacks: In this type, the hackers exploit a bug on the server, resulting in the system crashing, and hence, the server cannot provide service to the clients.
